Her father, William Warwick Sr., played the piano in local nightclubs, and her mother, Adele Bertha Scannell, was a singer. These early exposures to the world of music and performance undoubtedly laid the foundation for Warwick's passion and talent.

Growing up in the vibrant city of New Orleans, Warwick was exposed to an array of musical styles, including jazz, blues, and gospel. At age 14, she and her sister Dee Dee formed the vocal group The Dee Dee Warwick Singers, which later became The Dionne Warwick Singers. The group was a hit during the late 1950s and early 1960s, performing at clubs and making numerous radio appearances.

Warwick's solo career took off in the late 1960s after she signed with Scepter Records. In 1963, she recorded her first hit, "Don't Make Me Over." The single sold over two million copies, catapulting Warwick to stardom and setting her apart from the other girl groups of the era. Her mellow, soulful vocals were perfect for the popular doo-wop and pop music of the time.

Throughout the 1960s and 1970s, Warwick enjoyed a long string of hit singles, such as "Alfie," "I Say a Little Prayer," and "Do You Know the Way to San Jose." Her signature sound blended elements of pop, soul, and R&B, and her heartfelt lyrics resonated with audiences of all backgrounds.
